select 231221.999::time;

Compared to using a string literal, which is supported:
# select '231221.999'::time;
     time
--------------

timeline.bodyText:
DataType#value must not call DataType#implicitCast and perform the casting.
You would probably also have to adjust tests accordingly.
I'll copy-paste jordi's comment from the slack discussion regarding refactoring DataType and splitting
DataType#value for a better context.
Basically what I'm proposing is to split up value into multiple use cases because
right now it is a bit overloaded:
- cast, with a comment that this is only to be used via the cast function
 CastFunction, supports explicit/try/implicit
- valueForInsert - for the new implicit whitespace truncation case
- santizeType - for the cases where we currently use dataType#value to fix
a type read from source or so where an integer might have been stored as long
(This is mostly in the reference resolvers / column expression implementations)

For the timetz it seems that it'd be enough to implement the implicitCast, which is done already and keep the DataType#value as it was suggested in the previous comment.

timeline.message: Correct documentation, note regarding use of type in create/alter

Add type "time with time zone", alias timetz

This type is used as return value for time related functions, such as
"current_time".
Literals can be constructed using a string literal and a cast. Syntax
for the string literal:

time-element [offset]

    time-element: time-only [fraction]
    time-only:    HH[[:][mm[:]ss]]
    fraction:     '.' digit+
    offset:       {+ | -} time-only | geo-region
    geo-region:   As defined by ISO 8601.

fraction accepts up to 6 digits, delivering microsecond precision.
The type cannot be used in CREATE/ALTER statements.
